content.description:
Start up a sandy/slab face to a somewhat high first bolt. Then climb an ascending traverse left for 4 bolts with good pockets. The move past the second bolt is a bit awkward. Fun, pumpy pockets lead to the first crux. Crank on sandy huecos past this crux to a second crux which is poorly protected off a ledge. Don't blow the sandy slab move with poor feet or you'll hit the ledge. Continue up 2 more bolts to the anchor.

The 5th bolt (can't remember for sure) has a second stud that sticks out which may help identify the route.
content.location: This route is located on hueco wall 150 feet directly northwest of James Tower along with 4 other sport routes. The shiny bolts are obvious if you're on the approach to James Tower.

content.description: James Tower is the knob located on the west side of Buckhorn Wash approximately 1 mile north of the river.  There is a pullout on the west side of the road a little way past the tower.  To breach the chinle hike up the wash (along the chinle) to the west of the pullout until an easy scramble is reached.The route begins on the north side of the tower in a handcrack and winds left around to the south side and a big ledge.  The crack gets progressively larger as it curves around the tower.  There is an optional belay with three good bolts at approximately 75'.  The final pitch is a bolt ladder up the south face (10 or 11 clips).  There is a whole slew of bolts at the top offering several descent options.  With two ropes it is one rappel to the ground off the east side.  With one rope it would be two or three raps.
content.protection: Camalots 1-4 or 4.5, one set should suffice, two #3 would be useful. Long runners if you want to do it in two pitches.
